member.name: IDXCoreAdapterList.GetAdapter
member.summary: Retrieves a specific adapter by index from a DXCore adapter list object. For programming guidance, and code examples, see Using DXCore to enumerate adapters.
member.param: A zero-based index, identifying an adapter instance within the DXCore adapter list.
A reference to the globally unique identifier (GUID) of the interface that you wish to be returned in ppvAdapter. This is expected to be the interface identifier (IID) of .
The address of a pointer to an interface with the IID specified in the riid parameter. Upon successful return, *ppvAdapter (the dereferenced address) contains a pointer to the DXCore adapter created.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULTerror code.

|Return value|Description| |-|-| |DXGI_ERROR_DEVICE_REMOVED|The index is valid, but the adapter is no longer in a valid state.| |E_INVALIDARG|The provided index is not valid.| |E_NOINTERFACE|An invalid value was provided for riid.| |E_POINTER|nullptr was provided for ppvAdapter.|

member.name: IDXCoreAdapterList.GetAdapterCount
member.summary: Retrieves the number of adapters in a DXCore adapter list object. For programming guidance, and code examples, see Using DXCore to enumerate adapters.
member.returns: Returns the number of adapter items in the list.

member.name: IDXCoreAdapterList.GetFactory
member.summary: Retrieves an interface pointer to the DXCore adapter factory object. For programming guidance, and code examples, see Using DXCore to enumerate adapters.
member.param: A reference to the globally unique identifier (GUID) of the interface that you wish to be returned in ppvFactory. This is expected to be the interface identifier (IID) of .

The address of a pointer to an interface with the IID specified in the riid parameter. Upon successful return, *ppvFactory (the dereferenced address) contains a pointer to the existing DXCore adapter factory object. Before returning, the function increments the reference count on the factory object's interface.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULTerror code.
|Return value|Description| |-|-| |E_NOINTERFACE|An invalid value was provided for riid.| |E_POINTER|nullptr was provided for ppvFactory.|

member.name: IDXCoreAdapterList.IsAdapterPreferenceSupported
member.summary: Determines whether a specified value is understood by the current operating system (OS). You can call IsAdapterPreferenceSupported before calling .
member.param: A value that will be checked to see whether it's supported by the OS.
member.returns: Returns true if the sort type is understood by the current OS. Otherwise, returns false.

member.name: IDXCoreAdapterList.IsStale
member.summary: Determines whether changes to this system have resulted in this DXCore adapter list object becoming out of date. For programming guidance, and code examples, see Using DXCore to enumerate adapters.
member.returns: Returns true if, since generating the list, changes to system conditions have occurred that would cause this adapter list to become stale. Otherwise, returns false.

member.name: IDXCoreAdapterList.Sort
member.summary: Sorts a DXCore adapter list object based on a provided input array of sort criteria, where array items earlier in the array of criteria are given a higher weight. Sort helps you to more easily find your ideal adapter in an adapter list.
member.param: The number of elements that are in the array pointed to by the preferences parameter.
A pointer to a constant array of values, representing sort criteria.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULTerror code.
|Return value|Description| |-|-| |E_INVALIDARG|The numPreferences argument is zero, or the preferences argument is nullptr.|

member.name: IDXCoreAdapterList
member.summary: The IDXCoreAdapterList interface implements methods for retrieving adapter items from a generated list, as well as details about the list. IDXCoreAdapterList inherits from the interface. For programming guidance, and code examples, see Using DXCore to enumerate adapters.
